docs.title: Welcome to Trisha's Course Notes
docs.text: This is my home page. I will use it to organize and share my course notes.

docs.title: Setting up a dev container for Rust
docs.text:
• Primary author: Trisha

  • Reviewer: Cassidy Lowe

Note

This is me proving I can add an admonition to the page!

docs.title: Step by step tutorial on how to set up a Dev Container for Rust
Important:
docs.text: You will not need to install anything directly to your host machine since we are using a Dev Container. Since we are running Linux in our Dev Container, you should not expect to see a .exe file.

docs.title: Rust
docs.text: Rust is a programming language that acts as an alternative to C and C++ in many applications. It is used due to its superior performance, memory safety, and its concurrency.

docs.title: What you need to have installed before you continue:
Step 1: Creating a Directory, Initializing Git, and Creating a Readme
docs.text:
Run the following commands in your system's terminal:

mkdir rust-project
cd rust-project # (1)
  1. We have created and entered a new directory for the rest of our setup.

Next, run the following command

git init # (1)
  1. This is the git initialization command

Create a Readme file with the following code 

echo "# Rust README"> README.md
git add README.md
git commit -m "Initial commit with README" # (1)

docs.title: Step 2: Setting up a Remote Repository on GitHub
docs.text:
• Enter your internet browser and log into your github account. Navigate to the "Create a new repository" page.

  • Specify the following:

    Repository Name: rust-project

    Description: "Setting up a devcontainer for Rust."

    Visibility: Public

  • Do not initialize the repository with a README, .gitignore, or license.

  • Click create repository

docs.title: Step 3: Add the GitHub Repository as a Remote
docs.text:
• Run the following command in your terminal, replacing the "your-username" with your GitHub username: 
git remote add origin https://github.com/<your-username>/go-project.git # (1)

Check your default branch name with the subcommand git branch. If it's not main, rename it using the following command: 

git branch -M main.

Commit and push these changes to the GitHub repository by running the following command:

git push --set-upstream origin main # (1)

docs.title: Step 4: Adding a Dev Container Config
docs.text:
1. In VS Code, open the rust-project directory. (File > Open Folder).

  2. Install the Dev Containers extension for VS Code.

  3. Create a .devcontainer directory in the root of your project with the following file inside of this "hidden" configuration directory:

.devcontainer/devcontainer.json

Add the following code to your devcontainer.json file:

{
    "name": "Rust Project",
    "image": "mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/rust:latest",
    "customizations": {
        "vscode": {
        "settings": {
        "go.useLanguageServer": true
    },
    "extensions": [
      "rust-lang.rust-analyzer"
    ]
  }
}
}
